00026 enum tlm_phase { BEGIN_REQ, END_REQ, BEGIN_RESP, END_RESP };
00027 enum tlm_sync_enum { TLM_REJECTED, TLM_SYNC, TLM_SYNC_CONTINUE, TLM_COMPLETED };

00030 // Basic interfaces
00032 template <typename TRANS = tlm_generic_payload,
00033           typename PHASE = tlm_phase>
00034 class tlm_nonblocking_transport_if : public virtual sc_core::sc_interface {
00035 public:
00036   virtual tlm_sync_enum nb_transport(TRANS& trans,
00037                                      PHASE& phase,
00038                                      sc_core::sc_time& t) = 0;
00039 };

00041 template <typename TRANS = tlm_generic_payload>
00042 class tlm_blocking_transport_if : public virtual sc_core::sc_interface {
00043 public:
00044   virtual void b_transport(TRANS& trans) = 0;
00045 };

00048 // DMI interfaces for getting and invalidating DMI pointers:
00050 
00051 // The semantics of the forward interface are as follows:
00052 // 
00053 // - An initiator that want to get direct access to a target's memory region
00054 //   can call the get_direct_mem_ptr method with the address parameter set to
00055 //   the address that it wants to gain access to. The for_reads parameter
00056 //   specifies if the initiator wants to read or write to the target's DMI
00057 //   region. The initiator is responsible for calling the method with a
00058 //   freshly initialized tlm_dmi object either by using a newly constructed
00059 //   object, or by calling an existing object's init() method.
00060 // - The 'for_reads' parameter is necessary because read and write ranges are
00061 //   not necessarily identical. If they are, a target can specify that the
00062 //   range is valid for all accesses with the type attribute in the tlm_dmi
00063 //   structure.
00064 // - The interconnect, if any, needs to decode the address and forward the
00065 //   call to the corresponding target. It needs to handle the address exactly
00066 //   as the target would expect on a transaction call, e.g. mask the address
00067 //   according to the target's address width.
00068 // - If the target supports DMI access for the given address, it sets the
00069 //   data fields in the DMI struct and returns true.
00070 // - If a target does not support DMI access it needs to return false.
00071 //   The target can either set the correct address range in the DMI struct
00072 //   to indicate the memory region where DMI is disallowed, or it can specify
00073 //   the complete address range if it doesn't know it's memory range. In this
00074 //   case the interconnect is responsible for clipping the address range to
00075 //   the correct range that the target serves.
00076 // - The interconnect must always translate the addresses to the initiator's
00077 //   address space. This must be the inverse operation of what the
00078 //   interconnect needed to do when forwarding the call. In case the
00079 //   component wants to change any member of the tlm_dmi object, e.g. for
00080 //   its own latency to the target's latency, it must only do so *after* the
00081 //   target has been called. The target is always allowed to overwrite all
00082 //   values in the tlm_dmi object.
00083 // - In case the slave returned with an invalid region the bus/interconnect
00084 //   must fill in the complete address region for the particular slave in the
00085 //   DMI data structure.
00086 //
00087 // DMI hint optimization:
00088 // 
00089 // Initiators may use the DMI hint in the tlm_generic_payload to avoid
00090 // unnecessary DMI attempts. The recommended sequence of interface
00091 // method calls would be:
00092 //
00093 // - The initiator first tries to check if it has a valid DMI region for the
00094 //   address that it wants to access next.
00095 // - If not, it performs a normal transaction.
00096 // - If the DMI hint in this transaction is true, the initiator can try and
00097 //   get the DMI region.
00098 //
00099 // Note that the DMI hint optimization is completely optional and every
00100 // initiator model is free to ignore the DMI hint. However, a target is
00101 // required to set the DMI hint to true if a DMI request on the given address
00102 // with the given transaction type (read or write) would have succeeded.
00103 
00104 class tlm_fw_direct_mem_if : public virtual sc_core::sc_interface
00105 {
00106 public:
00107   virtual bool get_direct_mem_ptr(const sc_dt::uint64& address,
00108                                   bool for_reads,
00109                                   tlm_dmi& dmi_data) = 0;
00110 };
00111 
00112 // The semantics of the backwards call is as follows:
00113 //
00114 // - An interconnect component or a target is required to invalidate all
00115 //   affected DMI regions whenever any change in the regions take place.
00116 //   The exact rule is that a component must invalidate all those DMI regions
00117 //   that it already reported, if it would answer the same DMI request
00118 //   with any member of the tlm_dmi data structure set differently.
00119 // - An interconnect component must forward the invalidate_direct_mem_ptr call
00120 //   to all initiators that could potentially have a DMI pointer to the region
00121 //   specified in the method arguments. A safe implementation is to call
00122 //   every attached initiator.
00123 // - An interconnect component must transform the address region of an
00124 //   incoming invalidate_direct_mem_ptr to the corresponding address space
00125 //   for the initiators. Basically, this is the same address transformation
00126 //   that the interconnect does on the DMI ranges on the forward direction.
00127 // - Each initiator must check if it has a pointer to the given region and
00128 //   throw this away. It is recommended that the initiator throws away all DMI
00129 //   regions that have any overlap with the given regions, but this is not a
00130 //   hard requirement.
00131 //
00132 // - A full DMI pointer invalidation, e.g. for a bus remap can be signaled
00133 //   by setting the range: 0x0 - 0xffffffffffffffffull = (sc_dt::uint64)-1
00134 // - An initiator must throw away all DMI pointers in this case.
00135 //
00136 // - Under no circumstances a model is allowed to call the get_direct_mem_ptr
00137 //   from within the invalidate_direct_mem_ptr method, directly or indirectly.
00138 //
00139 class tlm_bw_direct_mem_if : public virtual sc_core::sc_interface
00140 {
00141 public:
00142   virtual void invalidate_direct_mem_ptr(sc_dt::uint64 start_range,
00143                                          sc_dt::uint64 end_range) = 0;
00144 };
00145 
00147 // debug interface for memory access
00149 //
00150 // This interface can be used to gain access to a targets memory or registers
00151 // in a non-intrusive manner. No side effects, waits or event notifications
00152 // must happen in the course of the method.
00153 //
00154 // Semantics:
00155 // - The initiator calls the transport_dbg method with the following arguments:
00156 //   . address: The start address that it wants to peek or poke.
00157 //   . num_bytes: The number of bytes that it requests to read or write.
00158 //   . do_read: Indicates a read or write access.
00159 //   . data: A pointer to the initiator-allocated data buffer, which must be
00160 //           at least num_bytes large. The data is always organized in the
00161 //           endianness of the machine.
00162 // - The interconnect, if any, will decode the address and forward the call to
00163 //   the appropriate target.
00164 // - The target must return the number of successfully transmitted bytes, where
00165 //   this number must be <= num_bytes. Thus, a target can safely return 0 if it
00166 //   does not support debug transactions.
00167 //
00168 class tlm_transport_dbg_if : public virtual sc_core::sc_interface
00169 {
00170 public:
00171   // The return value of defines the number of bytes successfully
00172   // transferred.
00173   virtual unsigned int transport_dbg(tlm_debug_payload& r) = 0;
00174 };
00175 
00177 // Combined interfaces
00179 
00180 // The forward non-blocking interface:
00181 template <typename TRANS = tlm_generic_payload,
00182           typename PHASE = tlm_phase>
00183 class tlm_fw_nb_transport_if
00184   : public virtual tlm_nonblocking_transport_if<TRANS, PHASE>
00185   , public virtual tlm_fw_direct_mem_if
00186   , public virtual tlm_transport_dbg_if
00187 {};
00188 
00189 // The backward non-blocking interface:
00190 template <typename TRANS = tlm_generic_payload,
00191           typename PHASE = tlm_phase>
00192 class tlm_bw_nb_transport_if
00193   : public virtual tlm_nonblocking_transport_if<TRANS, PHASE>
00194   , public virtual tlm_bw_direct_mem_if
00195 {};
00196 
00197 // The forward blocking interface:
00198 template <typename TRANS = tlm_generic_payload>
00199 class tlm_fw_transport_if
00200   : public virtual tlm_blocking_transport_if<TRANS>
00201   , public virtual tlm_fw_direct_mem_if
00202   , public virtual tlm_transport_dbg_if
00203 {};
00204 
00205 // The backward blocking interface:
00206 class tlm_bw_transport_if
00207   : public virtual tlm_bw_direct_mem_if
00208 {};
